detail.content: ﻿           Retention Rules Overview                                    Open topic with navigation           Retention Rules Overview      Retention rules define when a document will expire, in    the number of days, months, and years. Retention rules are independently created    and then can be assigned to a particular document class such that when assigning a    document class to a file, the retention rule of the class is applied to the file upon upload.      Retention rules have a name, description, owner, and an    expiration date including the option to not expire and make the file permanent. Additionally,    retention rules may be assigned a permissions template. For more information about permissions    templates, refer to Permissions Templates .      Once a retention rule is applied to a file, the owner of the file is    changed to the retention rule owner, the file's permissions are changed to those of the    retention rule’s permissions template and an expiration date is calculated for the file    based on the expiration day, month, year defined for the retention rule from the file's    creation date.       Add a Retention Rule                 Click the Setup link.             Click the Classification tab.       Click the Retention Rules tab.       Click the New Retention Rule button.       Define the Name . This is required .       Define the Description .       Define the Expiration Date . The expiration date is calculated using the creation date.    To make a file permanent, click the checkbox associated to No expiration - make document permanent .       Define the Permission template .       Define the Owner . This sets the owner of the file that is classified using    this retention rule. For example, once a file is uploaded and classified as Document Class A . Any of the    retention rules associated with Document Class A may be applied to the file.      Click OK .       Edit a Retention Rule                 Click the Setup link.             Click the Classification tab.       Click the Retention Rules tab.       Click the Edit icon associated to the retention rule you wish to edit.       Modify the Name . This is required .       Modify or create the Description .       Modify or create the Expiration Date . The expiration date is calculated using the creation date.    To make a file permanent, click the checkbox associated to No expiration - make document permanent .       Modify or create the Permission template .       Modify or create the Owner . This sets the owner of the file that is classified using    this retention rule. For example, once a file is uploaded and classified as Document Class A . Any of the    retention rules associated with Document Class A may be applied to the file.      Click OK .       Delete a Retention Rule                 Click the Setup link.             Click the Classification tab.       Click the Retention Rules tab.       Click the Delete icon associated to the retention rule you wish to delete.           Applying Retention Rules to Files      A retention rule can be applied can be applied to a file in one of    two ways:            Manually Applying a Retention Rule.  After a file has been    uploaded, navigate to the file's Manage Retention screen and apply the retention rule.       Applying a Retention Rule through a Document Class.  You can    apply a retention rule by classifying a file using a particular document class that has    already been assigned a retention rule. To add a retention rule to a document class,    edit the document class using the instructions,     Edit a Document Class . Once a file is classified,    the retention rule will be automatically applied.            Manually Apply a Retention Rule to a File                 Click the Home link.       Navigate to the file you wish to apply a retention rule.       Right-Click the selected file.       Select the Manage -> Retention option.       Select the Retention Rule from the drop-down menu.       Click the Apply button to save applied changes, or click the Exit button to exit.            Change a File's Retention Rule                 Click the Home link.       Navigate to the file you wish to apply a retention rule.       Right-Click the selected file.       Select the Manage -> Retention option.       Select a different Retention Rule from the drop-down menu.       Click the Apply button to save applied changes, or click the Exit button to exit.            Overriding a Retention Rule      You can override a file's retention rule to change the expiration date. At any    point before the expiration date, you can maintain the same retention rule for a    file but change the date it expires.      Change a File's Expiration Date                 Click the Home link.       Navigate to the file you wish to apply a retention rule.       Right-Click the selected file.       Select the Manage -> Retention option.       Click the Calendar icon to select the Expiration Date .       Select the Time from the drop-down menu.       The retention may be set to Permanent by selecting Yes from the drop-down menu.       Click the Apply button to save applied changes, or click the Exit button to exit.           Note.  Retention rules are different from the Records Management   Disposition Rules. Although Records Management is an optional module, it may be enabled for your   system. Disposition Rules are more rigorous policies determining the retention of a record and what   is to be done with a record once it reaches final disposition. Retention rules retain files according   to a certain length of time. Once that time passes, a file's permissions and ownership may be changed.   However, the file is not officially in final disposition as is the case in Records Management.

                    Glossary                       Acronyms                       Contacts & Resources                       Forms                       Technical Systems                       Frequently Asked Questions                       Case Studies                                                                   Financial Records Retention for Sponsored Programs                              Background   In general, Federal regulations require that financial records and supporting documents for an award must be retained for 3 years from the date of submission of the final expenditure report.     In certain cases, the documentation may need to be retained for three years after submission of the quarterly or annual financial report if required by the sponsor.     NYU Approach     Departments must maintain documentation, including emails, to support charges to a sponsored project that were not previously submitted through New York University (NYU) administrative systems such as:     Personnel Action Submission System (PASS/xPASS)   Maximus Effort Reporting System (ERS)   Journal Entry Management System (JEMS)   AP Workflow   Accounts Payable   Purchasing   See the Technical Systems page for more information about these administrative systems.       All Purchasing Card (P-Card) holders must retain documentation for these purchases.                                    Handbook Table of Contents                      Select an Option...           Handbook Home Purpose of the Handbook GNU Policies & Procedures Principal Investigator's Responsibility Budgeting Costing Policy Charging Administrative Expenses Accounting for Unallowable Costs Application of F&A Cost Rates F&A Cost Waivers Personnel Costs Fringe Benefit Rates Cost Sharing Opening or Modifying a Project Re-budgeting Prior Approvals (PAS) No-Cost Extension Cost Transfers Effort Reporting Salary Cap Administration Program Income Clinical Trials Financial Management Managing Sponsor Payments Domestic & Foreign Travel Memberships, Subscriptions & Professional Activities Managing Subawards Small Business Program Managing Equipment Recharge Center Policy Financial Reporting Award Closeout Internal & External Audits Financial Record Retention                                                    Submit Feedback        We'd like to hear what you think ...                                                    NYU Policy:        Financial Records Retention Policy for Sponsored Programs                   Full Policy & Downloadable PDF available at the University Policy Website.            Read the Policy                   Related Handbook & University Policies     Retention & Destruction of Records     Retention of and Access to Research Data                  Federal Guidelines     OMB Circular A-110                Technical Systems     Personnel Action Submission System (PASS/xPASS)   Maximus Effort Reporting System (ERS)   Journal Entry Management System (JEMS)   AP Workflow   eReq / iBuy   Go to the Handbook Technical Systems page                                              NYU Footer          Search      Directory      Campus Map      Events      Contact Us      Site Map      Copyright and Fair Use      Feedback         Unless otherwise noted, all content copyright New York University.
